title: fix(vendor): do not panic on relative specifier with scheme-like folder name
body:
I tried to vendor something for debugging purposes today and got a panic with jspm because it had some relative specifiers that looked like this:

```
import _regex2 from './npm:uc.micro@1.0.6/categories/Cc/regex!cjs';
```

```
============================================================
Deno has panicked. This is a bug in Deno. Please report this
at https://github.com/denoland/deno/issues/new.
If you can reliably reproduce this panic, include the
reproduction steps and re-run with the RUST_BACKTRACE=1 env
var set and include the backtrace in your report.

Platform: windows x86_64
Version: 1.21.1
Args: ["C:\\Users\\david\\AppData\\Local\\bvm\\binaries\\denoland\\deno\\1.21.1\\bin\\deno.exe", "vendor", "--force", "_config.ts"]

thread 'main' panicked at 'Could not find local path for npm:uc.micro@1/categories/Cc/regex!cjs', cli\tools\vendor\mappings.rs:143:11
```

The reason was a join was being done on `npm:uc.micro@1.0.6/categories/Cc/regex!cjs`, which would make it go absolute because "npm:" looks like a scheme.

body: See https://github.com/denoland/deno/pull/14419#issuecomment-1113127332

title: fix(cli): add dom.extras lib
body:
Closes: #12558
Fixes: #14344

This adds the `lib.dom.extras.d.ts` file and modifies the `lib.dom.d.ts` file to include it.  This solves the problem where users use the `lib: ["dom", "deno.ns"]` configuration when compiling their isomorphic TypeScript and the distributed version of the DOM library does not include every web standard API that Deno supports, and therefore causes confusing errors to the user.

This means we do make a one line edit to the distributed `lib.dom.d.ts` to include `lib.dom.extras.d.ts`.  This means that users don't have to explicitly include `"dom.extras"` when using the library, so for most users previous errors will just "go away".

This does establish a pattern now where we can add items Deno supports in advance of the TypeScript distribution supporting it while allowing more isomorphic code to type check safely.

title: fix(test/bench): Accept file protocol module specifier
body:
This PR fixes problem reported on #14375 where deno cli `test` and `bench` panic if given a module specifier as file URL

On MacOs it would not panic, but it fails with error saying it's not possible to read the file.

I was able to reproduce the issue with integration tests, and they are now passing with the fix.

A note about the solution: It will work only for files as File protocol URL, but not for directories. A directory will return an error saying it's not possible to read the file. I decided not implement the directory for 2 reasons:
1 - this is the simpler approach, and it's better to increment if you folks want than removing it.
2 - this is probably how http:// and https:// will work for `test` and `bench`. I didn't tested this, but by reading the code, they will not be able to handle a directory given by URL

If you would like, I can change the approach and make so it will check the URL (only file protocol), if it's a directory then we can recursively get all files, otherwise we don't change it.

`cargo test` failed with 4 errors, but they are unrelated to my change and I believe that is some problem with my setup, since they seem related to symlinks
<details>
  <summary>See failures here</summary>
failures:

        ./cli/tests/unit/stat_test.ts
        statSyncSuccess
        lstatSyncSuccess
        statSuccess
        lstatSuccess

test result: FAILED. 1003 passed (6 steps); 4 failed; 59 ignored; 0 measured; 0 filtered out (1m42s)
</details>

code was formatted with `./tools/format.js`
`./tools/lint.js` passed successfully with no errors
closes #14375

Bumped versions for 1.21.1

- [x] Crate versions are bumped correctly


title: fix: `deno task` should forward double hyphens
body:
When someone runs:

```
deno task node:test -- test-assert.js
```

It should forward everything after the task name like so:

```
Task node:test deno test --unstable --allow-all node/_tools/test.ts "--" "test-assert.js"
```

Currently it does:

```
Task node:test deno test --unstable --allow-all node/_tools/test.ts "test-assert.js"
```

title: fix(ext/http): truncate read bytes when streaming bodies
test(ext/console): Compact empty iterables when calling Deno.inspect with compact false
body:
<!--
Before submitting a PR, please read http://deno.land/manual/contributing

1. Give the PR a descriptive title.

  Examples of good title:
    - fix(std/http): Fix race condition in server
    - docs(console): Update docstrings
    - feat(doc): Handle nested reexports

  Examples of bad title:
    - fix #7123
    - update docs
    - fix bugs

2. Ensure there is a related issue and it is referenced in the PR text.
3. Ensure there are tests that cover the changes.
4. Ensure `cargo test` passes.
5. Ensure `./tools/format.js` passes without changing files.
6. Ensure `./tools/lint.js` passes.
-->
When `Deno.inspect` is called with the `compact` option set to `false`, empty iterables will still be compacted.

**Before**
```ts
Deno.inspect([], { compact: false });
// [
// 
// ]

Deno.inspect([], { compact: false, trailingComma: true });
// [
//   ,
// ]
```

**Now**
```ts
Deno.inspect([], { compact: false });
// []

Deno.inspect([], { compact: false, trailingComma: true });
// []
```

This is required to fix [this issue in denoland/deno_std](https://github.com/denoland/deno_std/issues/2144).

title: feat(ext/console): Add string abbreviation size option for "Deno.inspect"
body:
<!--
Before submitting a PR, please read http://deno.land/manual/contributing

1. Give the PR a descriptive title.

  Examples of good title:
    - fix(std/http): Fix race condition in server
    - docs(console): Update docstrings
    - feat(doc): Handle nested reexports

  Examples of bad title:
    - fix #7123
    - update docs
    - fix bugs

2. Ensure there is a related issue and it is referenced in the PR text.
3. Ensure there are tests that cover the changes.
4. Ensure `cargo test` passes.
5. Ensure `./tools/format.js` passes without changing files.
6. Ensure `./tools/lint.js` passes.
-->
Implements an option on `Deno.inspect` to set the maximum string size before it is truncated with an ellipsis.

This is required to fix [this issue in denoland/deno_std](https://github.com/denoland/deno_std/issues/2140).

title: perf(ext/http): faster is_content_compressible
body:
Cleanup + benches

Optimizing for the common case of "simple hits":
```
Before:
test compressible_complex_hit  ... bench:         113 ns/iter (+/- 3)
test compressible_complex_miss ... bench:         139 ns/iter (+/- 3)
test compressible_simple_hit   ... bench:          84 ns/iter (+/- 4)
test compressible_simple_miss  ... bench:          81 ns/iter (+/- 6)

After:
test compressible_complex_hit  ... bench:         126 ns/iter (+/- 1)
test compressible_complex_miss ... bench:         122 ns/iter (+/- 2)
test compressible_simple_hit   ... bench:          42 ns/iter (+/- 1)
test compressible_simple_miss  ... bench:         122 ns/iter (+/- 2)

After (with phf):
test compressible_complex_hit  ... bench:          76 ns/iter (+/- 1)
test compressible_complex_miss ... bench:          67 ns/iter (+/- 22)
test compressible_simple_hit   ... bench:          19 ns/iter (+/- 0)
test compressible_simple_miss  ... bench:          67 ns/iter (+/- 6)
```

title: perf(serde_v8): zero-copy StringOrBuffer
body:
```
Before:
test de_sob_buf_16kb      ... bench:         597 ns/iter (+/- 16)
test de_sob_buf_1b        ... bench:          90 ns/iter (+/- 3)
test de_sob_buf_1kb       ... bench:         169 ns/iter (+/- 3)
test de_sob_buf_512kb     ... bench:      23,829 ns/iter (+/- 441)
test de_sob_str_1kb       ... bench:         555 ns/iter (+/- 6)
test de_sob_str_6b        ... bench:          76 ns/iter (+/- 0)

After:
test de_sob_buf_16kb      ... bench:          32 ns/iter (+/- 1)
test de_sob_buf_1b        ... bench:          32 ns/iter (+/- 2)
test de_sob_buf_1kb       ... bench:          32 ns/iter (+/- 1)
test de_sob_buf_512kb     ... bench:          32 ns/iter (+/- 2)
test de_sob_str_1kb       ... bench:         465 ns/iter (+/- 14)
test de_sob_str_6b        ... bench:          48 ns/iter (+/- 1)
```

Closes #14355

title: refactor(lsp): store all the assets in Rust when initializing
body:
The total size of the assets stored in the TS isolate is 0.7MB. I think it's worth it to store these up front in the Rust code when initializing because it simplifies the code a decent amount.

1. Removes the concept of "cached assets" vs "uncached assets" (reduces the chance of making a mistake as well)
2. Gets rid of a lot of asyncness

title: perf(ext/http): fast path for uncompressed bodies
body:
Brings back the nice juicy numbers seen in https://github.com/denoland/deno/pull/14284

sample.txt is 5MB

`main`:
```
wrk -t8 -c20 -d10s http://localhost:8080/sample.txt
Running 10s test @ http://localhost:8080/sample.txt
  8 threads and 20 connections
  Thread Stats   Avg      Stdev     Max   +/- Stdev
    Latency    38.43ms    4.80ms  83.32ms   91.27%
    Req/Sec    51.87      9.99    60.00     62.87%
  4192 requests in 10.10s, 20.53GB read
Requests/sec:    414.91
Transfer/sec:      2.03GB
```

This PR:
```
Running 10s test @ http://localhost:8080/sample.txt
  8 threads and 20 connections
  Thread Stats   Avg      Stdev     Max   +/- Stdev
    Latency    17.58ms    2.53ms  44.05ms   88.56%
    Req/Sec   114.07     12.06   141.00     67.20%
  9179 requests in 10.10s, 44.87GB read
Requests/sec:    908.86
Transfer/sec:      4.44GB
```

title: tests: unflake streaming compression tests
body:
`curl -I` closes the connection after headers have arrived, but we want it to
also receive the body (even if we don't use it), so the server doesn't encounter
an unexpected EOF. To do this we now use `curl -i`.

```
Running 10s test @ http://localhost:4507/sample.txt
```

title: fix: `--watch` was losing items
body: We need to ensure this works if the `recv()` never completes due to being used in a `tokio::select`

title: perf(fmt/lint): incremental formatting and linting
body:
## Formatting

Before on deno_std:

```ps
> Measure-Command { deno fmt } | Select-Object -Property TotalMilliseconds
Checked 929 files

TotalMilliseconds
-----------------
          414.208
> Measure-Command { deno fmt } | Select-Object -Property TotalMilliseconds
Checked 929 files

TotalMilliseconds
-----------------
         415.6013
```

After (see second run):

```ps
> Measure-Command { ../deno/target/release/deno fmt } | Select-Object -Property TotalMilliseconds
Checked 929 files

TotalMilliseconds
-----------------
         415.8299
> Measure-Command { ../deno/target/release/deno fmt } | Select-Object -Property TotalMilliseconds
Checked 929 files

TotalMilliseconds
-----------------
         118.6008
```

## Linting

Before on deno_std:

```
> Measure-Command { deno lint } | Select-Object -Property TotalMilliseconds
Checked 873 files

TotalMilliseconds
-----------------
         464.5036
> Measure-Command { deno lint } | Select-Object -Property TotalMilliseconds
Checked 873 files

TotalMilliseconds
-----------------
         461.2106
```

After (see second run... first run is just by chance faster):

```
> Measure-Command { ../deno/target/release/deno lint } | Select-Object -Property TotalMilliseconds
Checked 873 files

TotalMilliseconds
-----------------
         451.739

V:\deno_std [main ↑10 +0 ~1 -0 !]
> Measure-Command { ../deno/target/release/deno lint } | Select-Object -Property TotalMilliseconds
Checked 873 files

TotalMilliseconds
-----------------
          114.018
```

This will be a big performance improvement if people cache their DENO_DIR on the CI too (the 400ms above is with 20 cores which would be much slower with only 2 cores on GH actions). Edit: Actually, the cache would need to be keyed on the CLI version... I'm not sure how that could work.

Closes #10906

title: fix: panic when trying to pledge permissions before restoring previous pledge
body:
This commit fixes and edge case, where testing/benching code could pledge new
permission set before restoring the previous pledge. 

Appropriate panics were added and tests that assert that process is killed
in case of "recursive pledge".

Closes https://github.com/denoland/deno/issues/13831

This commit adds "aggregated" field to "deno_core::JsError" that stores
instances of "JsError" recursively to properly handle "AggregateError"
formatting. Appropriate logics was added to "PrettyJsError" and 
"console" API to format AggregateErrors.

title: refactor: Move source map lookups to core
body: This had been blocking lots of other cleanups as well. Namely the following transformations gradually faced by `JsError` have all been moved up front to `JsError::from_v8_exception()`: finding the first non-`deno:` source line [[old code]](https://github.com/denoland/deno/blob/f7e7f548499eff8d2df0872d1340ddcdfa028c45/cli/source_maps.rs#L60-L80); moving `JsError::script_resource_name` etc. into the first error stack in case of syntax errors [[old code]](https://github.com/denoland/deno/blob/f7e7f548499eff8d2df0872d1340ddcdfa028c45/cli/fmt_errors.rs#L259-L273); source mapping `JsError::script_resource_name` etc. when wrapping the error even though the frame locations are source mapped earlier [[old code]](https://github.com/denoland/deno/blob/f7e7f548499eff8d2df0872d1340ddcdfa028c45/cli/main.rs#L132-L133); removing `JsError::{script_resource_name,line_number,start_column,end_column}` entirely in favour of `js_error.frames.get(0)`. We also no longer pass a js-side callback to `core/02_error.js` from cli. I avoided doing this on previous occasions because the source map lookups were in an awkward place.

title: feat(test): format user code output
body: Closes https://github.com/denoland/deno/issues/14192 This commit changes "deno test" to better denote user output coming from test cases. This is done by printing "---- output ----" and "---- output end ----" markers if an output is produced. The output from "console" and "Deno.core.print" is captured, as well as direct writes to "Deno.stdout" and "Deno.stderr". To achieve that new APIs were added to "deno_core" crate, that allow to replace an existing resource with a different one (while keeping resource ids intact). Resources for stdout and stderr are replaced by pipes.

title: perf(runtime): read entire files in single ops
body:
Pending on https://github.com/denoland/deno/pull/14221

Sync benchmarks:
```
hyperfine '../deno/target/release/deno run -A --no-check test.js' 'node test.js' 'deno run -A --no-check test.js'
Benchmark 1: ../deno/target/release/deno run -A --no-check test.js
  Time (mean ± σ):     163.3 ms ±   2.4 ms    [User: 11.2 ms, System: 152.9 ms]
  Range (min … max):   160.3 ms … 169.3 ms    18 runs

Benchmark 2: node test.js
  Time (mean ± σ):     171.6 ms ±   1.7 ms    [User: 19.5 ms, System: 151.7 ms]
  Range (min … max):   169.5 ms … 175.7 ms    17 runs

Benchmark 3: deno run -A --no-check test.js
  Time (mean ± σ):     172.4 ms ±   1.3 ms    [User: 19.7 ms, System: 155.7 ms]
  Range (min … max):   169.9 ms … 174.4 ms    17 runs

Summary
  '../deno/target/release/deno run -A --no-check test.js' ran
    1.05 ± 0.02 times faster than 'node test.js'
    1.06 ± 0.02 times faster than 'deno run -A --no-check test.js'
```

Async benchmarks:
```
hyperfine '../deno/target/release/deno run -A --no-check test_async.mjs' 'node test_async.mjs' 'deno run -A --no-check test_async.mjs'
Benchmark 1: ../deno/target/release/deno run -A --no-check test_async.mjs
  Time (mean ± σ):     308.3 ms ±   3.3 ms    [User: 11.6 ms, System: 297.8 ms]
  Range (min … max):   305.1 ms … 316.9 ms    10 runs

Benchmark 2: node test_async.mjs
  Time (mean ± σ):     363.8 ms ±   1.0 ms    [User: 40.8 ms, System: 333.1 ms]
  Range (min … max):   362.3 ms … 366.1 ms    10 runs

Benchmark 3: deno run -A --no-check test_async.mjs
  Time (mean ± σ):     672.7 ms ±   5.4 ms    [User: 251.3 ms, System: 453.0 ms]
  Range (min … max):   666.1 ms … 682.2 ms    10 runs

Summary
  '../deno/target/release/deno run -A --no-check test_async.mjs' ran
    1.18 ± 0.01 times faster than 'node test_async.mjs'
    2.18 ± 0.03 times faster than 'deno run -A --no-check test_async.mjs'
```

title: feat(repl): add "--eval-file" flag to execute a script file on startup
body:
Syntax

deno repl --script /path/to/script

Purpose

The purpose of this change is to provide deno with an option that is analogous to python -i /path/to/source, which runs the specified source file as additional prelude and then shows the user a REPL that can be used to enter more code. Python's -i flag is very useful for prototyping and experimentation. It is also useful for students who want to set up example structures and then examine them in an interactive session to improve their understanding of the language. This feature is different from "deno run" because "deno run" exits once the specified module exits. deno run is not interactive.

Example

``` $ cat a.js let a=5; $ deno repl --script a.js Deno 1.20.5 exit using ctrl+d or close() > a 5 > ```

Related Issues

This feature (and closely related features) have been previously discussed: 1. #3173 2. #7425 3. #7938 4. #11317 5. #13256

Related Work

Related work includes the implementation of the --eval flag (https://github.com/denoland/deno/pull/11590) which allows the user to specify the prelude code as command-line parameters. This is useful, but may be inconvenient for larger preludes.

Potential Concerns

1. --script may be a bad flag name. #13256 suggests the name --eval-file. --prelude is another possibility, but it may be confusing because cli/tools/repl/session.rs already specifies some initial commands in a PRELUDE variable. 2. There is discussion by @dsherret on #13256 that this feature may not be worth it. It is already possible to expose module exports efficiently via --eval. Do we want a way to expose local variables in an interactive session? I think the answer is "probably." For example, students may find it useful to use preludes which define variables in a global scope because they don't understand modules yet. Other users may find it useful during prototyping when the amount of code is small and not worth structuring as a module. 3. There is discussion by @dsherret on #11317 about possibly modifying the script code to rewrite module import paths, etc. This implementation does not attempt to do that. 4. If the user specifies both --script and --eval, which should be executed first? In this implementation, I execute --script first. 5. Perhaps we should support multiple prelude files? The current implementation supports only one. 6. Perhaps we should support http:// in addition to file system access? 7. This is my first Rust program, so there may be bugs or non-idiomatic patterns in the code.

title: refactor(core): OpCtx
body:
Avoiding need for js-visible OpIDs, alternative to https://github.com/denoland/deno/pull/14224

The core idea is that each op is provided with a single pointer providing its relevant rust-side context, what it points to may change (e.g: we might get rid of explicit op_ids and track OpMetrics in the ctx) and how we pass it will likely evolve from using the callback's data to a JS-side External 1st arg for Fast API callables

Moderate improvement of `op_baseline`:

```
Before:
test bench_is_proxy   ... bench:      17,695 ns/iter (+/- 487)
test bench_op_async   ... bench:     277,137 ns/iter (+/- 10,404)
test bench_op_nop     ... bench:      19,595 ns/iter (+/- 1,267)
test bench_op_pi_json ... bench:      23,339 ns/iter (+/- 1,257)

After:
test bench_is_proxy   ... bench:      17,738 ns/iter (+/- 953)
test bench_op_async   ... bench:     273,845 ns/iter (+/- 7,598)
test bench_op_nop     ... bench:      18,535 ns/iter (+/- 794)
test bench_op_pi_json ... bench:      23,068 ns/iter (+/- 1,499)
```

## TODO

- [x] Fix up metrics (getting op id/name pairs)
